8BF31C9C35984987BA5A454651CF2A5C.description: Solve a given probability problem involving two independent events.

01763A7468554D7199EAE0F25C653C4D.description: Conduct a probability experiment for an outcome involving two independent events, with and without technology, to compare the experimental probability with the theoretical probability.

40B02D7545AB41BC808799643A8D5C08.description: Determine the theoretical probability of a given outcome involving two independent events.

03F277DDC7154A8FA010C2B1A018DE74.description:
Students will be expected to conduct a probability experiment to compare the theoretical
probability (determined using a tree diagram, table, or other graphic organizer) and experimental
probability of two independent events.

631471E428AE4B888C0CE0B10E08AFF7.description: Provide an example of an event with a probability of 0 or 0% (impossible) and an example of an event with a probability of 1 or 100% (certain).

B472186F47D84A988E39601CE31C7CEA.description:
Determine the probability of a given outcome occurring for a given probability experiment,
and express it as a ratio, fraction, and percent.

BEA18F75A35B4CD682DFF9323BC22B01.description: Students will be expected to express probabilities as ratios, fractions, and percents.

095DA2F3290047889D03941970E2E647.description: Interpret a given or constructed circle graph to answer questions.

5BF2EFF016364D6C8843E3BA03D77E9B.description: Translate percentages displayed in a circle graph into quantities to solve a given problem.

3C03E647E38341C5AA083676D860E9D5.description: Find and compare circle graphs in a variety of print and electronic media, such as newspapers, magazines, and the Internet.

D40F5C746BA24A1A8792B27B7197884C.description: Create and label a circle graph, with technology, to display a given set of data

1B84F35659854EDDA53556BE951DF5BD.description:
Identify common attributes of circle graphs, such as
o title, label, or legend
o the sum of the central angles is 360०
o the data is reported as a percent of the total, and the sum of the percents is equal to
100% .

FC3C01A6681A4883AC568A4BD81FD064.description: Students will be expected to construct, label, and interpret circle graphs to solve problems

EC46001F78BC4647BF22ADB58ADFBC26.description: Provide examples of situations in which outliers would and would not be used in reporting the measures of central tendency

01DD24F38B024C03A79408673C1AD0F1.description: Identify outliers in a given set of data, and justify whether or not they are to be included in reporting the measures of central tendency.

CA4ADE308128476998FCEDD9650DB977.description: Explain the effect of outliers on the measures of central tendency for a given data set.

657DBA3156E74E9F83DC7113FBA7D842.description: Analyze a given set of data to identify any outliers.

DAC985C6ACE249CEB5647668D080C36E.description:
Students will be expected to determine the effect on the mean, median, and mode when an
outlier is included in a data set.

756EF32D76154CC19E8EF4763749A771.description: Solve a given problem involving the measures of central tendency

06213660CFA34C1EBF0F8551F69B49DE.description: Provide a context in which the mean, median, or mode is the most appropriate measure of central tendency to use when reporting findings.

979368353BDB44AF9E18D0A9E8974EAE.description: Determine the range for a given set of data.

B6B0DACA6CD44F5CB51C5E7659FCBCA2.description:
Determine mean, median, and mode for a given set of data, and explain why these values
may be the same or different.

42EA5DAEF9514B3C9F4FF8F431535B81.description:
Students will be expected to demonstrate an understanding of central tendency and range by
determining the measures of central tendency (mean, median, mode) and range
determining the most appropriate measures of central tendency to report findings.

7BD807AC9482457DA1BDE054FA125D39.description: Plot the point corresponding to a given integral ordered pair on a Cartesian plane with units of 1, 2, 5, or 10 on its axes.

C825710B7BE14E0DA7A17769FFBA2C32.description: Identify the location of a given point in any quadrant of a Cartesian plane using an integral ordered pair.

49DC58898BE74CE980060837C0BB0E1F.description:
Label the axes of a four quadrant Cartesian plane and identify the origin.
G02.02 Identify the location of a given point in any quadrant of a Cartesian plane using an integral
ordered pair.
G02.03 Plot the point corresponding to a given integral ordered pair on a Cartesian plane with units
of 1, 2, 5, or 10 on its axes.

B9FE5FCE6EAD4E1E98E16CB1DC887087.description:
Students will be expected to identify and plot points in the four quadrants of a Cartesian plane,
using integral ordered pairs.

AB393803DAFF42E0B61B01A26280D37B.description: Solve a given problem involving the area of triangles, parallelograms, and/or circles.

946F357898E447B08830BC64385E32E0.description: Generalize a rule to create a formula for determining the area of a given circle.

962850CE9FDE4C668D64817B1D36D0A3.description: Illustrate and explain how to estimate the area of a circle without the use of a formula.

C7B7A3DDAF3B474BBC2A31032029C600.description: Generalize a rule to create a formula for determining the area of parallelograms.

7239F067BE124720BDC26E5B6D3E2963.description: Illustrate and explain how the area of a rectangle can be used to determine the area of a parallelogram.

E35F9EFEABB54625987F58F92B61DBC9.description: Generalize a rule to create a formula for determining the area of triangles.

200A412450BA42D9993EF51AE85353A9.description:
Illustrate and explain how the area of a rectangle can be used to determine the area of a
triangle.

C352D4D8EAC2436B8D6782D26AE64E32.description:
Students will be expected to develop and apply a formula for determining the area of triangles,
parallelograms, and circles.

FF3785E032C24FEF843C62ADE7A23D50.description: Solve a given contextual problem involving circles.

8098F1B0633D454ABF13576A4ACFF5AA.description: Draw a circle with a given radius or diameter, with and without a compass.

6BC9D027DC094377A3EA6D67B81F7E60.description: Explain, using an illustration, that the sum of the central angles of a circle is 360°.

C19B73A379D14FD0A62ED244BD3999BC.description: Explain that, for all circles, pi is the ratio of the circumference to the diameter (C/D) and its value is approximately 3.14.

E8E81A126E264465A2CA78FAA8A38EEE.description: Illustrate and explain that the circumference is approximately three times the diameter in a given circle.

18F2D021755747A0B15F53559881A579.description: Illustrate and explain that the diameter is twice the radius in a given circle.

1595C71E20FD4A119D51D62DE481D32C.description:
M01 Students will be expected to demonstrate an understanding of circles by:
describing the relationships among radius, diameter, and circumference
▪ relating circumference to pi
▪ determining the sum of the central angles
▪ constructing circles with a given radius or diameter
▪ solving problems involving the radii, diameters, and circumferences of circles.

384563DB719D49868DFC97124E43EBFF.description: PR07.05 Substitute a possible solution for the variable in a given linear equation into the original linear equation to verify the equality.

0FC84E0ED1C347B8A844988038B26DCF.description: PR07.04 Verify the solution to a given linear equation using concrete materials and diagrams.

40A0E8F0E97A4F32975B647EED0C12E1.description: PR07.03 Solve a given problem using a linear equation and record the process.

3AC5306FA79C451C8815D18F4D40A54F.description: PR07.02 Draw a visual representation of the steps used to solve a given linear equation.

E81412E321A840069C92BAB8CA3DA134.description:
PR07.01 Represent a given problem with a linear equation, and solve the equation using concrete
models.

9E26058D93B74FDFA4BACA20AE9DAA7B.description:
Students will be expected to model and solve, concretely, pictorially, and symbolically, where a,
b, and c are whole numbers, problems that can be represented by linear equations of the form
ax + b = c; ax = b; x ÷ a = b, a ≠ 0

BDFC676BAF7C4B8D905E8C15189F447A.description: Substitute a possible solution for the variable in a given linear equation into the original linear equation to verify the equality.

BF87020EC2F04A6E8E35505E291C042B.description: Verify the solution to a given linear equation using concrete materials and diagrams.

F30AAB44686E4D0BB26C5F85AB17CEB3.description: Solve a given problem using a linear equation and record the process.

73B3757D060B4C12A2C4CD4D146A8874.description: Draw a visual representation of the steps required to solve a given linear equation.

99418BC220A84690A42B3278AF475107.description:
Represent a given problem with a linear equation, and solve the equation using concrete
models.

59AD57F076D64495B2EF104C71BF36F8.description:
Students will be expected to model and solve, concretely, pictorially, and symbolically, problems
that can be represented by one-step linear equations of the form x + a = b, where a and b are integers.

7DAD10F33E4E45E6B627D1507DB32671.description: Substitute a value for an unknown in a given expression and evaluate the expression.

7D5D70B237744F949973C0BF4A81691D.description: Students will be expected to evaluate an expression given the value of the variable(s).

8DD67555D44D449981783AC3CB4AD07C.description: Provide an example of an expression and an equation and explain how they are similar and different.

D8FCC70C79E64FBD880434A73313337C.description: Explain what a variable is and how it is used in a given expression.

457F402B423146E595F1B8E0B1219C35.description:
Identify and provide an example of a constant term, numerical coefficient, and variable in an
expression and an equation.

5936417D309145BF9F2C63329E295651.description: Students will be expected to explain the difference between an expression and an equation.

32D00652F06D4693BEA9F01248091D5C.description: Solve a given problem by applying preservation of equality

34C1C37DF80C43639C22188B52709745.description: Write equivalent forms of a given equation by applying the preservation of equality, and verify using concrete materials (e.g., 3b = 12 is equivalent to 3b + 5 = 12 + 5 or 2r = 7 is equivalent to 3(2r) = 3(7).

75D6589E2DB344C292712EE873989238.description:
Model the preservation of equality for each of the four operations, using concrete materials
and/or pictorial representations; explain the process orally; and record the process
symbolically.

B954CA3861114BD9A50C5DF6D140F42E.description:
Students will be expected to demonstrate an understanding of preservation of equality by
modelling preservation of equality, concretely, pictorially, and symbolically
applying preservation of equality to solve equations.

33BFA9243A62495C82EC545967E37CA4.description: Match a given set of graphs to a given set of linear relations.

984B48484BA74B509DB3A236A5F5852B.description: Match a given set of linear relations to a set of graphs.

D2C0F6DACFB546FC9948F6DEFACBD270.description: Describe, using everyday language, in spoken or written form, the relationship shown on a graph to solve problems.

0428102FC37949A1B4FDCD89E306A738.description: Sketch the graph from a table of values created for a given linear relation, and describe the patterns found in the graph to draw conclusions (e.g., graph the relationship between n and 2n + 3).

502800881C8D47CCA2F67C6EF3CD6BD7.description: Create a table of values for a given linear relation by substituting values for the variable.

E221835F5249475099EFD81F96A8B1AA.description: Create a table of values, using a linear relation, and graph the table of values (limited to discrete elements).

9C081E9EA89049449A4DAF8E47DC5F21.description:
Students will be expected to create a table of values from a linear relation, graph the table of
values, and analyze the graph to draw conclusions and solve problems.

161C5BDFFF2344A6B8B2918C7645AAD5.description: Represent a pattern in the environment using a linear relation.

134A46CB49AB43F992C475E767776912.description: Provide a context for a given linear relation that represents a pattern.

6EEDB5C6D724495481BF65DF40D3F4C8.description: Formulate a linear relation to represent the relationship in a given oral or written pattern.

2372B3F4095E4EA6A812581C8D3D5D29.description:
Students will be expected to demonstrate an understanding of oral and written patterns and
their equivalent linear relations.

C034107ED8BE4CD09B68540D5D267E18.description: Position a given set that includes positive fractions, positive decimals, and/or whole numbers on a number line and explain strategies used to determine order.

96B2BBF5B61246C1A35FC556426D4C53.description: Position the numbers of a given set by placing them on a number line that contains benchmarks, such as 0 and 1 or 0 and 5.

270203045BB64B73ACC6373EB2A31D03.description: Identify incorrectly placed numbers in an ordered sequence or on a number line.

2E7B2D8B1EA44A80B6AF64ED597354D5.description: Identify a number that would be between two given numbers in an ordered sequence or on a number line.

F90228591A674AF7A4C7F99B11A08A26.description: Compare and order the numbers of a given set that includes positive fractions, positive decimals, and/or whole numbers in ascending or descending order and verify the result using a variety of strategies.

2842D9EB63AF4A3E8833A0B671CA34FD.description: Position a given set of positive decimals on a number line and explain strategies used to determine order.

19981EE8A89A4E6B81C5535DFD43F406.description: Position a given set of positive fractions, including mixed numbers and improper fractions, on a number line; and explain strategies used to determine order.

A382B4BBEE904547884470022754E915.description:
Position proper fractions with like and unlike denominators from a given set on a number
line, and explain strategies used to determine order.

562FBB5069524D89806B8DC67339D75A.description:
Students will be expected to compare, order, and position positive fractions, positive decimals (to
thousandths), and whole numbers by using benchmarks, place value, and equivalent fractions and/or
decimals.

625F2C1617A74E76956FE1A2C08BEADC.description: Solve a given problem involving the addition and subtraction of integers.

DD1959E81090447CAD48C16535586269.description: Illustrate the relationship between adding integers and subtracting integers.

B90AEF7A3B9A4D308E5EB7A79B8D2315.description: Subtract two given integers, using concrete materials and/or pictorial representations, and record the process symbolically.

DA5D003688A3486EAB921F8142A7914E.description: Add two given integers, using concrete materials and/or pictorial representations, and record the process symbolically.

DEF6E782D7914818A5B63D2C8232DBFC.description: Illustrate, using a number line, the results of adding or subtracting negative and positive integers.

02F1382825BD4AEBBBF31778517B41CA.description:
Explain, using concrete materials such as integer tiles and diagrams, that the sum of
opposite integers is zero.

8BEBF08156AA49529752A1B7149974C7.description:
Students will be expected to demonstrate an understanding of addition and subtraction of
integers, concretely, pictorially, and symbolically

92416449CC4F4BFBBF10A4364585682E.description: Solve a given problem involving the addition or subtraction of positive fractions or mixed numbers, and determine if the solution is reasonable.

84108537236A4A38BE9001418FCE27B7.description: Simplify the solution to a given problem involving the sum or difference of two positive fractions or mixed numbers.

B9DE133142CA49CA9DE0369733B8D44E.description: Simplify a given positive fraction or mixed number by identifying the common factor between the numerator and denominator.

632B07B77DA6457EBA94F3765762D977.description: Determine the difference of two given positive fractions or mixed numbers with unlike denominators.

6DBAC20BF53E418C8234C340DFF0B4A1.description: Determine the sum of two given positive fractions or mixed numbers with unlike denominators.

5EDAC573C00244D7A7C0817FFA0CA89E.description: Determine a common denominator for a given set of positive fractions or mixed numbers.

A192FF15850A493EB37EF737882D4A35.description: Determine the difference of two given positive fractions or mixed numbers with like denominators.

4D5D9778031C4F9B9AF0FCBA3E43FF38.description: Determine the sum of two given positive fractions or mixed numbers with like denominators.

BBD5BC6CF82D402A8AD3714B097D5C5B.description: Determine the sum or difference of fractions mentally, when appropriate.

F67BD6490F8442E8BE4971B360A4D5B1.description: Model addition and subtraction of given positive fractions or given mixed numbers, using concrete and pictorial representations, and record symbolically.

9CF676A0737D41EDB1B9B40A68595899.description: Use benchmarks to estimate the sum or difference of positive fractions or mixed numbers.

A3F53B6A792B4448AC5AC586F05A1270.description:
Students will be expected to demonstrate an understanding of adding and subtracting positive
fractions and mixed numbers, with like and unlike denominators, concretely, pictorially, and
symbolically (limited to positive sums and differences).

3A55008DD1124BF9BAA081A66623DF61.description: Express a given terminating decimal as a fraction.

846583923F134BF197F0FC1C4B580856.description: Express a given repeating decimal as a fraction.

052AA7D751384D3B85694E90F165137B.description: Express a given fraction as a terminating or repeating decimal.

60074F5D418241F08A0F8AD32EF40819.description: Sort a given set of fractions as repeating or terminating decimals.

5127AF5884794529AB4548919B17EBDE.description: Match a given set of fractions to their decimal representations.

221AEFB323B949919AE139E0D0755801.description: Predict the decimal representation of a given fraction using patterns.

EF56032C7F3542009AF681BF0CD1F85A.description:
Students will be expected to demonstrate an understanding of the relationship between positive
terminating decimals and positive fractions and between positive repeating decimals (with one or two
repeating digits) and positive fractions.

44A6F6F590DC41FDA020E0E426A7C613.description: Determine the answer to a given percent problem where the answer requires rounding, and explain why an approximate answer is needed (e.g., total cost including taxes).

4CBC11F9B9D046BA8D7DBC60E8A19656.description: Solve a given problem that involves finding a percent.

48873633C8CA48BD8849791FCDAAEBA1.description: Use estimation to determine an approximate answer or the reasonableness of an answer.

9EDB596E4B0944FB8361E3002DF305A5.description: Use mental mathematics to solve percent problems, when appropriate.

59690047C3B3490D95326EFBF5DED4F1.description: Express a given percent as a decimal or fraction.

6549332A4E59458A974BBE31432921C9.description:
Students will be expected to solve problems involving percents from 1% to 100% (limited to whole
numbers).

38F9F384815B4520B34C20B8CFE0568C.description: Solve a given problem that involves operations on decimals (limited to thousandths), taking into consideration the order of operations.

5EEDDE1451FF41018C952EBEBF7BE2D8.description: Solve a given problem involving the multiplication or division of decimal numbers with more than two-digit multipliers or more than one-digit divisors (whole numbers or decimals) with the use of technology.

A5D247E7A8074A4880B7AA76ECC57F3E.description: Solve a given problem involving the multiplication or division of decimal numbers with more than two-digit multipliers or more than one-digit divisors (whole numbers or decimals) with the use of technology.

CF2EBA147F854F28B6CDAB1AF675AA8B.description: Solve a given problem involving the multiplication or division of decimal numbers with twodigit multipliers or one-digit divisors (whole numbers or decimals) without the use of technology.

F7E4E09B83834DF49CF5E96866D53832.description: Create and solve a given problem involving the division of decimal numbers.

6E0ED0A0796740D3B6A389B894B91C93.description: Create and solve a given problem involving the multiplication of decimal numbers.

A142F055EBAC4AADA2B0D16C46437F63.description: Create and solve a given problem involving the subtraction of decimal numbers.

56D6A60D77334823AE3E450146FD9CCF.description: Create and solve a given problem involving the addition of two or more decimal numbers.

8EE244134EEC4F819FE2BF2FDE8B12B1.description: Represent concretely, pictorially, and symbolically the multiplication and division of decimal numbers.

883E23C77B124ECBBDC8A18E69D71ADF.description: Use estimation to determine the appropriate place value when calculating the quotient.

63F1C76CAF4D4831905A266492374929.description: Use estimation to determine the appropriate place value when calculating the product.

67CCE16ACD2B494F8D71515DA62D9448.description:
Use estimation to determine the appropriate place value when calculating the sum or
difference.N02.11 Check the reasonableness of solutions using estimation.

847AA087A21346C88C4C6E8D78E1D16E.description:
Students will be expected to demonstrate an understanding of the addition, subtraction,
multiplication, and division of decimals to solve problems (for more than one-digit divisors or more
than two-digit multipliers, the use of technology is expected).

CDCBA98AF2A54612B87D363A6A6CBDC1.description: Explain, using an example, why numbers cannot be divided by 0.

C6EBC5BFA4C8432FB7C1D2530F4E7E28.description: Determine the factors of a given number using the divisibility rules.

A9B16F41B3B64719A99DD83474A0840D.description: Determine if a given number is divisible by 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 9, or 10, and explain why.

DF8E8783346643DF8E5DA9976DFF3AC8.description:
Students will be expected to determine and explain why a number is divisible by 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 9,
or 10, and why a number cannot be divided by 0.
